title: Static friction - effect of changing force on box

content.question: In Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, a force of magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> is exerted horizontally on a box resting on a rough, horizontal surface. A force exerted horizontally with a magnitude greater than <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> will cause the box to slide. In Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the force <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> is removed and a force of magnitude <math alttext="the fraction F over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> is then exerted on the same box. Which of the following statements about the box in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> must be true?

choices.label: The force of static friction on the box will be equal to <math alttext="the fraction F over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>.
The force of static friction on the box will be equal to <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math>.
The box will begin sliding to the left.
The box will begin sliding to the right.

content.answer: The force of static friction on the box will be equal to <math alttext="the fraction F over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>.
